title: Yevhen Seleznyov
text:
Yevhen Oleksandrovych Seleznyov (; born 20 July 1985) is a Ukrainian professional <a href="Association%20football">footballer</a> who plays as a <a href="Forward%20%28association%20football%29">striker</a> for <a href="FC%20Mynai">Mynai</a>.
He previously played three spells at <a href="Shakhtar%20Donetsk">Shakhtar Donetsk</a>, winning the <a href="UEFA%20Cup">UEFA Cup</a> in <a href="2009%20UEFA%20Cup%20Final">2009</a>, and a domestic <a href="Double%20%28association%20football%29">double</a> three years later. He was the league's top scorer in their double-winning season, and maintained the honour the following season with Dnipro.
A full international since 2008, Seleznyov has earned over 50 caps for <a href="Ukraine%20national%20football%20team">Ukraine</a>, scoring 11 international goals. He was part of their squad when they co-hosted <a href="UEFA%20Euro%202012">UEFA Euro 2012</a>.
Career.
Shakhtar Donetsk.
Born in <a href="Makiivka">Makiivka</a>, <a href="Ukrainian%20SSR">Ukrainian SSR</a>, <a href="Soviet%20Union">Soviet Union</a>, Yevhen Seleznyov is a product of the Shakhtar Donetsk and the <a href="FC%20Shakhtar%20Makiivka">Shakhtar Makiivka</a> academies. After being promoted to professional level in 2002, he had difficult time to secure its place in the first team and played for the club's second and third teams in lower leagues as well as the club's reserve team. His chance to distinguish himself at premiers Seleznyov gained in the winter of 2007 when he went on a one-and-a-half year loan deal to <a href="FC%20Arsenal%20Kyiv">Arsenal Kyiv</a>. Seleznyov was one of the top goal-scorers in the <a href="2007%E2%80%9308%20Ukrainian%20Premier%20League">2007–08 Ukrainian Premier League</a>, having scored 17 goals in 24 games. Soon after returning to Donetsk he was called up to the Ukrainian national team.
On completion of his loan, he returned to Donetsk and signed a 5-year deal. He scored his first goal for Shakhtar on 3 August against <a href="Illichivets%20Mariupol">Illichivets Mariupol</a> in a 3–0 victory· He played three matches in the <a href="UEFA%20Champions%20League">UEFA Champions League</a>, including a 5–0 home win over <a href="FC%20Basel">FC Basel</a>, in which he came on as a substitute and scored a goal.
He made two appearances in the <a href="UEFA%20Cup">UEFA Cup</a> as they won it in his first season at the club: on 19 February 2009, a minute after replacing <a href="Oleksandr%20Hladkyy">Oleksandr Hladkyy</a>, he headed in <a href="J%C3%A1dson">Jádson</a>'s free kick with his first touch of the game to score past <a href="Tottenham%20Hotspur">Tottenham Hotspur</a> goalkeeper <a href="Heurelho%20Gomes">Heurelho Gomes</a> to open a 2–0 win.
Dnipro Dnipropetrovsk.
On 25 July 2009, Seleznyov signed with rivals <a href="Dnipro%20Dnipropetrovsk">Dnipro Dnipropetrovsk</a> in a deal worth €4.5 million. That same day, he scored his first goal for Dnipro on his debut against <a href="Metalist%20Kharkiv">Metalist Kharkiv</a>.
In the next two seasons, Seleznyov established himself at Dnipro as a target man of good scoring ability, especially with his head. He was the top scorer of the <a href="2010%E2%80%9311%20Ukrainian%20Premier%20League">2010–11 Ukrainian Premier League</a> season with 17 goals in 24 games.
Return to Shakhtar Donetsk.
On 22 June 2011, Dnipro re-sold him to his previous club <a href="FC%20Shakhtar%20Donetsk">Shakhtar Donetsk</a>. The transfer fee was undisclosed but it is estimated to be around €5 million. In September 2011 Seleznyov was involved in multi car <a href="pile%20up">pile up</a>, while driving his <a href="Maserati">Maserati</a> in <a href="Donetsk">Donetsk</a>. Luckily nobody got physically hurt.
At the end of the <a href="2011-12%20Ukrainian%20Premier%20League">2011–12</a> season, Seleznyov was Shakhtar's top league goalscorer, and joint top league scorer outright with <a href="Maicon%20%28footballer%2C%20born%20May%201988%29">Maicon</a> with 14, despite the latter scoring two penalties. Seleznyov scored against <a href="APOEL%20F.C.">APOEL Nicosia</a> in the Champions League, in a 2–0 win.
Return to Dnipro Dnipropetrovsk.
On 29 August 2012, Seleznyov went back to Dnipro for an undisclosed fee.
On 7 May 2015, Seleznyov scored an 80th-minute equaliser in the <a href="2014%E2%80%9315%20UEFA%20Europa%20League">Europa League</a> semi-final first leg against <a href="S.S.C.%20Napoli">Napoli</a>, making it 1–1 and giving Dnipro the <a href="away%20goals">away goals</a> advantage heading into the second leg. In the second leg, at the <a href="Olimpiyskyi%20National%20Sports%20Complex">Olympic Stadium</a> in <a href="Kyiv">Kyiv</a>, a week later, Seleznyov scored the only goal of the game as Dnipro won 1–0, to go through to their first European <a href="2015%20UEFA%20Europa%20League%20Final">final</a> on 27 May 2015, 2–1 winners on aggregate. Dnipro lost the final 3–2, with Seleznyov entering the game in the 78th minute.
Kuban Krasnodar.
On 25 February 2016, he signed a contract with the Russian team <a href="FC%20Kuban%20Krasnodar">FC Kuban Krasnodar</a>. Seleznyov was released by Dnipro to Kuban for free under a condition that Seleznyov will forgive the club's debts which exceed over 1 mln Euros. Before signing with Kuban, Seleznyov refused offers from some clubs of the English <a href="Premier%20League">Premier League</a>.
On 11 May 2016 in an interview with the channel Football 1 Yevhen Seleznyov confirmed that he terminated the contract with Kuban. Following that season Kuban relegated to the <a href="Russian%20First%20League">Russian First League</a>.
Second return to Shakhtar Donetsk.
On 14 May 2016, <a href="FC%20Shakhtar%20Donetsk">FC Shakhtar Donetsk</a> confirmed that the club had signed a 2-year contract with Seleznyov. In December 2016 on mutual consent Seleznyov left the club.
Kardemir Karabükspor.
Less than a week later after leaving Shakhtar, it was announced that Seleznyov signed a contract with the Turkish <a href="Kardemir%20Karab%C3%BCkspor">Kardemir Karabükspor</a> which only recently returned to the <a href="Turkish%20Super%20League">Turkish Super League</a>.
Akhisarspor.
On 10 May 2018, Seleznyov helped <a href="Akhisar%20Belediyespor">Akhisar Belediyespor</a> win their first professional trophy, the <a href="2017%E2%80%9318%20Turkish%20Cup">2017–18 Turkish Cup</a>.
International career.
On 24 May 2008, he made his first appearance for the <a href="Ukrainian%20national%20football%20team">Ukrainian national football team</a> in a friendly against <a href="Netherlands%20national%20football%20team">Netherlands</a>. He scored his first international goal against <a href="Norway%20national%20football%20team">Norway</a> in <a href="Dnipropetrovsk">Dnipropetrovsk</a> on 19 November, the only goal of the game.
Seleznyov was a member of Ukraine's squad as they co-hosted <a href="UEFA%20Euro%202012">UEFA Euro 2012</a>, but did not enter the field of play in their <a href="UEFA%20Euro%202012%20Group%20D">group stage exit</a>.
On 6 September 2013, Seleznyov was one of nine Ukrainian players to score in their 9–0 thrashing of <a href="San%20Marino%20national%20football%20team">San Marino</a> at the <a href="Arena%20Lviv">Arena Lviv</a> in <a href="2014%20FIFA%20World%20Cup%20qualification">qualification for the following year's World Cup</a>. He scored his first international two-goal haul on 15 October in the reverse fixture, as Ukraine won 8–0 in <a href="Serravalle%20%28San%20Marino%29">Serravalle</a>; the result qualified Ukraine for <a href="2014%20FIFA%20World%20Cup%20qualification%20%28UEFA%29">the play-offs</a>, which they lost to <a href="France%20national%20football%20team">France</a>.
